review_title: It's all I had for awhile
job_title: Visiting Lecturer in Lake Charles, LA
pros: When I moved here for my wife's job, they took me on and trained me to teach online and I've been doing so for several years. They also contributed to my professional development. Although they recently cut my class load without warning, this was due to budget cuts on the part of the state government, so I can't blame them directly.
cons: They upped the cap for online classes to 40 without consulting us. I have been teaching accelerated classes for the Center for Adult Learning (CALL), but they are the same as regular courses in content, which is writing-enriched. The idea of grading 40 students' writing assignments at more than twice the rate of a regular course angers me.

job_title: Specialist in Lake Charles, LA
pros: The people are determined and dedicated to the cause. Can be a really fun work environment depending on your department/team. Everything is done with students in mind, which is nice.
cons: The University is on the smaller side and doesn't have a large budget/many donors. The campus is in desperate need of new equipment, updated processes, and 21st century innovation. The faculty and staff do the best with what they have, but the outdated processes often cause confusion and unnecessary delays. You might bump heads with people who have been here 15+ years who are unwilling to change - "We've always done it this way" is something you might hear a lot.

job_title: Instructor in Lake Charles, LA
pros: I loved working there and am truly sad to have left. Every person I met whether faculty, staff, or admin was friendly. The university is small enough to be personable and fair and good to their faculty, but large enough to stretch out academically. The students are good-hearted people who want to learn, and Louisiana culture can't be beat.
cons: The only downsides are financial. The state doesn't properly fund higher education so the campus is not as up-to-date as it could be. For the same reasons, many of the salaries are stagnant. It's a shame. McNeese is a top-notch regional university that's suffering right now because the state legislature doesn't understand how higher ed works.

review_title: Love MSU- hate the Accounting Department
job_title: Accounting in Lake Charles, LA
pros: I love working at McNeese overall. It is such an amazing atmosphere to be in- fun during HC week and attending the various events around campus.  The benefits (health, life, dental, vision, holidays, vacation/sick time) are ALMOST worth staying for.
cons: My boss in particular complains when you do not work enough, but will not allow you to earn OT.  They will be the first to throw you under the bus if something didn't go their way.  My boss is so very cold- no room for mistakes.

job_title: Instructor in Lake Charles, LA
pros: Being able to teach independently and be creative with lesson plans, students are very appreciative on a whole, low expectations for student progess, reading student journal assignments
cons: I taught a english class without prior teaching experience. All we had to guide us was a heniously ironic inadequate coursebook compiled by a McNeese professor with the help of undergraduate students. The irony is that it was supposed to instruct how to write properly, but in itself was a poorly organized and executed compostion riddled with every error it sought to correct in student writing.

job_title: in Lake Charles, LA
pros: Excellent opportunity for graduate students with decent pay and discount tuition fee. I worked in the MBA program as well as the Frazar Memorial Library. In MBA program, I helped a very nice professor with his projects. We submitted several papers together and are waiting for publications. I love working in the library. Just remember to stay out of inter-department conflicts and you should be fine.
cons:
Some drama in the library but not a big deal.
They are letting go of many employees due to budget cut.

job_title: Custodian in Lake Charles, LA
pros: State benefits if you stay long enough.  Relaxed work environment, and time off.
cons: Where should I begin with the cons of working at McNeese.  I have been a custodian here at McNeese for the past 10 years.  If you are hired on as a new custodian you have to go through a contracting agency ABM, and they can't seem to keep their workers anymore then a month.  We make 10 bucks an hour and that's not going to cut it.  I have also worked at the Old Ranch where the cafeteria is located and not only can you find mold everywhere but it reeks of mold everywhere as well.  As a person eating there I am not sure how you can enjoy your meal when you know the place is invested with mold, I am very surprised OSHA, or any state food inspectors have not inspected this place out yet.  I have also seen raccoons in this building along with plants growing up on top of the roof.  Next time you walk past the old ranch you should pay attention to all the plants/weeds growing up on that roof, its a disgrace.  I know I wouldn't send my two kids here knowing all the problems they have, my kids went elsewhere.  I have also experienced very cold temperatures in the winter in this building and very hot temperatures in the summer in this building.  The building doesn't have a proper HVAC system, and when you call maintenance they are actually incapable of fixing the problem.   What do you expect when they are not licensed HVAC repair men.  The students pay 8K for in-state tuition, 13K for out-of state tuition, and 19K for being an international student, don't you think they deserve more for their money than what McNeese is currently providing them.  McNeese has recently invested heavily in the mens BB program in which attendance is abysmal to say the least.  McNeese should of taken that 45 million on the new HHP/basketball arena and built a new student union/cafeteria, where students could actually get some use out of the facilities.  How many McNeese BB players were drafted in the past 30 years?  None, when will you guys wake up and smell the coffee, or should I say mold.
